title: Impulse - change in momentum of falling brick

content.question: A student drops a brick, which falls freely for <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> seconds before landing on the ground. The impulse delivered to the brick by the gravitational force during the first second on the fall is <math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and the impulse delivered to the brick by the gravitational force during the second second is <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Which of the following correctly compares <math alttext="J sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="J sub 1 is less than J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>1</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>, because the average momentum of the brick is larger during the second second of the fall.

<math alttext="J sub 1 is less than J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>1</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>, because the magnitude of the gravitational force increases as the brick gets closer to the ground.

<math alttext="J sub 1 equals J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>, because the gravitational force and the total time are the same for both intervals.

<math alttext="J sub 1 equals J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>, because the momentum of the brick is constant.

content.answer: <math alttext="J sub 1 equals J sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>J</mi><mtext>2</mtext></msub></math>, because the gravitational force and the total time are the same for both intervals.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
